revision.text:
[[Image:M D Vaden Design.jpg|200px|right|thumb|One example of a maintained landscape from [[Beaverton, Oregon|Beaverton]], [[Oregon]]]]
'''Landscape maintenance''' (or '''groundskeeping''') is the art and vocation of keeping a landscape healthy, clean, safe and attractive, typically in a [[residential garden|garden]], [[yard (land)|yard]], [[park]], institutional setting or [[Estate (house)|estate]]. Using [[tool|tools]], supplies, knowledge, physical exertion and skills, a [[groundskeeper]] may plan or carry out annual plantings and harvestings, periodic weeding and fertilizing, other [[gardening]], [[lawn]] care, [[snow removal]], [[driveway]] and path maintenance, [[shrubbery|shrub]] pruning, [[topiary]], lighting, [[fence|fencing]], [[swimming pool]] care, runoff drainage, and [[irrigation]], and other jobs for protecting and improving the [[topsoil]], [[plants]], and garden accessories.
Groundskeepers may also deal with local [[animal]]s (including [[bird]]s, [[rodent]]s, [[reptile]]s, [[insect]]s, and [[domesticated|domestic]] animals or [[pet]]s), and create means to attract or repel them, as desired or necessary. A garden may also be designed to include exotic animals, such as a [[koi]] pond. In larger estates, groundskeepers may be responsible for providing and maintaining habitat for wild animals.
== Landscape maintenance industry == Some private research firms estimate that landscape maintenance is a $77 billion industry in [[North America]], with nearly 1 million employees working for over 400,000 businesses as of February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibisworld.com/industry/default.aspx?indid=1497 |title=Landscaping Services in the US: Market Research Report |publisher=ibisworld.com |date=2016-02-01 |accessdate=2016-04-12}}</ref>
The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) estimated in May 2015 that statistical group 37-3011 "Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers" numbered 895,600 with a median annual wage of $25,030.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes373011.htm |title=Occupational Employment and Wages, May 2015 |publisher=bls.gov |date=2015-05-01 |accessdate=2016-04-12}}</ref> The BLS says of this group: "Workers typically perform a variety of tasks, which may include any combination of the following: sod laying, mowing, trimming, planting, watering, fertilizing, digging, raking, sprinkler installation, and installation of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units".
== See also == * [[Gardening]] * [[Groundskeeper]] * [[Landscape architecture]] * [[List of domesticated animals]] * [[List of domesticated plants]] * [[Property manager]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Landscape Maintenance}}
[[Category:Landscape architecture]]

page.title: List of Academy Awards for Walt Disney

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
{{featured list}} [[Image:Walt Disney Snow white 1937 trailer screenshot (13).jpg|alt=A color photograph of [[Walt Disney]] sitting behind a desk. Seven figurines are standing before him.|thumb|right|250px|Cartoonist and film producer [[Walt Disney]], with the [[Seven Dwarfs]].]] [[Walt Disney]] (1901–1966) won or received a total of twenty-six [[Academy Awards]], and holds the record for most Academy Awards in history.{{cite web |url=http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/help/statistics/Gen-NomsFacts.pdf |title=Nominee Facts – Most Nominations and Awards |accessdate=2015-03-23 |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6h22F5eNX?url=http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/help/statistics/Gen-NomsFacts.pdf |archivedate=2016-04-25 |df= }} He won twenty-two competitive Academy Awards from a total of fifty-nine nominations, and also holds the records for most wins and most nominations for an individual in history. Disney won his first competitive Academy Award and received his first [[Honorary Academy Award]] at the [[5th Academy Awards]] (1932). He received the Honorary Academy Award for the creation of [[Mickey Mouse]] and won the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Academy Award for Best Short Subject (Cartoon)]] for the film ''[[Flowers and Trees]]''. In the seven Academy Award ceremonies that followed ([[6th Academy Awards|6th]]–[[12th Academy Awards|12th]]), Disney consecutively earned nominations and won in the same category. Disney received three more Honorary Academy Awards, one in [[11th Academy Awards|1939]] and two in [[14th Academy Awards|1942]]. At the [[26th Academy Awards]] (1954), Disney won the Academy Award in all four categories in which he was nominated: Best Short Subject (Cartoon), [[Academy Award for Best Live Action Short Film|Best Short Subject (Two-reel)]], [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature|Best Documentary (Feature)]], and [[Academy Award for Best Documentary (Short Subject)|Best Documentary (Short Subject)]].{{cite news|first=Jim |last=Korkis |url=http://travel.usatoday.com/alliance/destinations/mouseplanet/post/2012/02/And-The-Academy-Award-Goes-To%E2%80%A6Walt-Disney/632850/1 |title=And The Academy Award Goes To....Walt Disney! |accessdate=March 3, 2015 |publisher=MousePlanet.com |work=[[USA Today]] |date=February 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004040809/http://travel.usatoday.com/alliance/destinations/mouseplanet/post/2012/02/And-The-Academy-Award-Goes-To%E2%80%A6Walt-Disney/632850/1 |archivedate=October 4, 2012 }} In [[37th Academy Awards|1965]], Disney earned his sole [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] nomination, for the film ''[[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]''. He was [[List of posthumous Academy Award winners and nominees|posthumously awarded]] his final Academy Award in [[41st Academy Awards|1969]] for ''[[Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day]]''. == Competitive Academy Awards == [[Image:Disney Display Case.JPG|alt=|thumb|right|250px|The display case in the lobby of the [[Walt Disney Family Museum]], in [[San Francisco]], displays many of the Academy Awards that Walt Disney won or received. {{Use British English|date=November 2014}} This is a '''list of the bird species recorded in Réunion'''. The avifauna of [[Réunion]] include a total of 91 species, of which four are [[Endemism in birds|endemic]], 21 have been [[Introduced species|introduced]] by humans and 20 are rare or accidental. One species listed is [[Local extinction|extirpated]] in Réunion and is not included in the species count. Six species are globally threatened.
This list's [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] treatment (designation and sequence of orders, families and species) and nomenclature (common and scientific names) follow the conventions of ''[[The Clements Checklist of Birds of the World]]'', 6th edition. The family accounts at the beginning of each heading reflect this taxonomy, as do the species counts found in each family account. Introduced and accidental species are included in the total counts for Réunion.
The following tags have been used to highlight several categories. Not all species fall into one of these categories. Those that do not are commonly occurring native species.
* (A) '''[[Vagrancy (biology)|Accidental]]''' - a species that rarely or accidentally occurs in Réunion * (E) '''[[Endemic]]''' - a species endemic to Réunion * (I) '''[[Introduced species|Introduced]]''' - a species introduced to Réunion as a consequence, direct or indirect, of human actions * (Ex) '''[[Local extinction|Extirpated]]''' - a species that no longer occurs in Réunion although populations exist elsewhere * (X) '''[[Extinct]]''' - a species formerly found on Réunion, but no longer exists alive globally __NOTOC__ {| class="toccolours" style="margin:0 auto; width:55em; clear:both;" !Table of contents |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Non-passerines''': [[#Albatrosses|Albatrosses]] • [[#Shearwaters and petrels|Shearwaters and petrels]] • [[#Austral storm petrels|Austral storm petrels]] • [[#Tropicbirds|Tropicbirds]] • [[#Boobies and gannets|Boobies and gannets]] • [[#Frigatebirds|Frigatebirds]] • [[#Bitterns, herons and egrets|Bitterns, herons and egrets]] • [[#Ibises and spoonbills|Ibises and spoonbills]] • [[#Flamingos|Flamingos]] • [[#Ducks, geese and swans|Ducks, geese and swans]] • [[#Hawks, kites and eagles|Hawks, kites and eagles]] • [[#Caracaras and falcons|Caracaras and falcons]] • [[#Pheasants and partridges|Pheasants and partridges]] • [[#Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots|Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots]] • [[#Crab-plover|Crab-plover]] • [[#Pratincoles and coursers|Pratincoles and coursers]] • [[#Buttonquails|Buttonquails]] • [[#Plovers and lapwings|Plovers and lapwings]] • [[#Sandpipers and allies|Sandpipers and allies]] • [[#Gulls, terns, and skimmers|Gulls, terns, and skimmers]] • [[#Pigeons and doves|Pigeons and doves]] • [[#Old World parrots|Old World parrots]] • [[#Typical owls|Typical owls]] • [[#Swifts|Swifts]] • [[#Typical rollers|Typical rollers]] |- | class="wikitable nowraplinks" style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; text-align:center;"| '''Passerines''': [[#Swallows and martins|Swallows and martins]] • [[#Cuckooshrikes|Cuckooshrikes]] • [[#Bulbuls|Bulbuls]] • [[#Old World flycatchers|Old World flycatchers]] • [[#Monarch flycatchers|Monarch flycatchers]] • [[#White-eyes|White-eyes]] • [[#Starlings|Starlings]] • [[#Weavers and allies|Weavers and allies]] • [[#Waxbills and allies|Waxbills and allies]] • [[#Siskins, crossbills and allies|Siskins, crossbills and allies]] • [[#Sparrows|Sparrows]] |- | style="padding:0 2% 0 2%; ==Albatrosses== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Diomedeidae]]
*[[Wandering albatross]], ''Diomedea exulans'' *[[Black-browed albatross]], ''Thalassarche melanophris'' (A) *[[Salvin's albatross]], ''Thalassarche salvini'' (A) *[[Indian yellow-nosed albatross]], ''Thalassarche carteri'' *[[Sooty albatross]], ''Phoebetria fusca'' (A) *[[Light-mantled albatross]], ''Phoebetria palpebrata'' (A)
==Shearwaters and petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Procellariidae]]
*[[Antarctic giant petrel]], ''Macronectes giganteus'' *[[Hall's giant petrel]], ''Macronectes halli'' (A) *[[Cape petrel]], ''Daption capense'' *[[Mascarene petrel]], ''Pterodroma aterrima'' *[[Barau's petrel]], ''Pterodroma baraui'' *[[Broad-billed prion]], ''Pachyptila vittata'' (A) *[[Slender-billed prion]], ''Pachyptila belcheri'' (A) *[[Flesh-footed shearwater]], ''Ardenna carneipes'' *[[Wedge-tailed shearwater]], ''Ardenna pacificus'' *[[Tropical shearwater]], ''Puffinus bailloni''
==Austral storm petrels== '''Order''': [[Procellariiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Oceanitidae]]
*[[Wilson's storm petrel]], ''Oceanites oceanicus'' *[[White-bellied storm petrel]], ''Fregetta grallaria'' (A)
==Tropicbirds== '''Order''': [[Phaethontiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Phaethontidae]]
*[[White-tailed tropicbird]], ''Phaethon lepturus''
==Boobies and gannets== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Sulidae]]
*[[Masked booby]], ''Sula dactylatra'' *[[Red-footed booby]], ''Sula sula''
==Frigatebirds== '''Order''': [[Suliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Fregatidae]]
*[[Great frigatebird]], ''Fregata minor'' (A) *[[Lesser frigatebird]], ''Fregata ariel'' (A)
==Bitterns, herons and egrets== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Ardeidae]]
*[[Cattle egret]], ''Bubulcus ibis'' *[[Striated heron]], ''Butorides striata''
==Ibises and spoonbills== '''Order''': [[Pelecaniformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Threskiornithidae]]
*[[Réunion ibis]], ''Threskiornis solitarius'' (X)
==Flamingos== '''Order''': [[Phoenicopteriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Phoenicopteridae]]
*[[Greater flamingo]], ''Phoenicopterus roseus'' *[[Lesser flamingo]], ''Phoenicopterus minor''
==Ducks, geese and swans== '''Order''': [[Anseriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Anatidae]]
*[[Réunion sheldgoose]], ''Alopochen kervazoi'' (X) *[[White-faced whistling duck]], ''Dendrocygna viduata'' (A) *[[Meller's duck]], ''Anas melleri'' (I) *[[Garganey]], ''Spatula querquedula''
==Hawks, kites and eagles== '''Order''': [[Accipitriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Accipitridae]]
*[[Black kite]], ''Milvus migrans'' *[[Réunion harrier]], ''Circus maillardi''
==Caracaras and falcons== '''Order''': [[Falconiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Falconidae]]
*[[Eleonora's falcon]], ''Falco eleonorae'' *[[Sooty falcon]], ''Falco concolor'' (A)
==Pheasants and partridges== '''Order''': [[Galliformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Phasianidae]]
*[[Chinese francolin]], ''Francolinus pintadeanus'' *[[Grey francolin]], ''Francolinus pondicerianus'' (I) *[[Madagascan partridge]], ''Margaroperdix madagarensis'' (I) *[[Common quail]], ''Coturnix coturnix'' (I) *[[Blue quail]], ''Excalfactoria adansonii'' (I) *[[Jungle bush quail]], ''Perdicula asiatica'' (I) *[[Red junglefowl]], ''Gallus gallus'' (I)
==Rails, crakes, gallinules and coots== '''Order''': [[Gruiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Rallidae]]
*[[Common moorhen]], ''Gallinula chloropus'' *[[Mascarene coot]], ''Fulica newtonii'' (X)
==Crab-plover== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Dromadidae]]
*[[Crab-plover]], ''Dromas ardeola''
==Pratincoles and coursers== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Glareolidae]]
*[[Oriental pratincole]], ''Glareola maldivarum'' (A) *[[Madagascar pratincole]], ''Glareola ocularis''
==Buttonquails== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Turnicidae]]
*[[Madagascan buttonquail]], ''Turnix nigricollis'' (I)
==Plovers and lapwings== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Charadriidae]]
*[[Black-bellied plover]], ''Pluvialis squatarola'' *[[Common ringed plover]], ''Charadrius hiaticula'' *[[Greater sandplover]], ''Charadrius leschenaultii''
==Sandpipers and allies== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Scolopacidae]]
*[[Bar-tailed godwit]], ''Limosa lapponica'' *[[Whimbrel]], ''Numenius phaeopus'' *[[Eurasian curlew]], ''Numenius arquata'' *[[Common greenshank]], ''Tringa nebularia'' *[[Terek sandpiper]], ''Xenus cinereus'' *[[Common sandpiper]], ''Actitis hypoleucos'' *[[Ruddy turnstone]], ''Arenaria interpres'' *[[Sanderling]], ''Calidris alba'' *[[Curlew sandpiper]], ''Calidris ferruginea''
==Gulls, terns, and skimmers== '''Order''': [[Charadriiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Laridae]]
*[[Great crested tern]], ''Thalasseus bergii'' *[[Roseate tern]], ''Sterna dougallii'' (A) *[[Bridled tern]], ''Onychoprion anaethetus'' (A) *[[Sooty tern]], ''Onychoprion fuscatus'' *[[Whiskered tern]], ''Chlidonias hybrida'' (A) *[[White-winged tern]], ''Chlidonias leucopterus'' (A) *[[Lesser noddy]], ''Anous tenuirostris'' (A) *[[Brown noddy]], ''Anous stolidus'' *[[White tern]], ''Gygis alba'' (A)
==Pigeons and doves== '''Order''': [[Columbiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Columbidae]]
*[[Malagasy turtle dove]], ''Nesoenas picturatus'' (I) *[[Zebra dove]], ''Geopelia striata'' (I)
==Old World parrots== '''Order''': [[Psittaciformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Psittaculidae]]
*[[Rose-ringed parakeet]], ''Psittacula krameri'' (I) ==Typical owls== '''Order''': [[Strigiformes]] {{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Strigidae]]
*[[Verreaux's eagle-owl]], ''Bubo lacteus''
==Swifts== '''Order''': [[Apodiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Apodidae]]
*[[Mascarene swiftlet]], ''Aerodramus francicus''
==Typical rollers== '''Order''': [[Coraciiformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Coraciidae]]
*[[Broad-billed roller]], ''Eurystomus glaucurus'' (A)
==Swallows and martins== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Hirundinidae]]
*[[Mascarene martin]], ''Phedina borbonica''
==Cuckooshrikes== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Campephagidae]]
*[[Réunion cuckooshrike]], ''Coracina newtoni'' (E)
==Bulbuls== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Pycnonotidae]]
*[[Red-whiskered bulbul]], ''Pycnonotus jocosus'' (I) *[[Réunion bulbul]], ''Hypsipetes borbonicus'' (E)
==Old World flycatchers== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Muscicapidae]]
*[[Réunion stonechat]], ''Saxicola tectes'' (E)
==Monarch flycatchers== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Monarchidae]]
*[[Mascarene paradise flycatcher]], ''Terpsiphone bourbonnensis''
==White-eyes== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Zosteropidae]]
*[[Réunion grey white-eye]], ''Zosterops borbonicus'' (E) *[[Réunion olive white-eye]], ''Zosterops olivaceus'' (E)
==Starlings== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Sturnidae]]
*[[Common myna]], ''Acridotheres tristis'' (I)
==Weavers and allies== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Ploceidae]]
*[[Village weaver]], ''Ploceus cucullatus'' (I) *[[Red fody]], ''Foudia madagascariensis'' (I) *[[Red-billed quelea]], ''Quelea quelea'' (I)
==Waxbills and allies== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Estrildidae]]
*[[Common waxbill]], ''Estrilda astrild'' (I) *[[Red avadavat]], ''Amandava amandava'' (I) *[[Nutmeg mannikin]], ''Lonchura punctulata'' (I)
==Siskins, crossbills and allies== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Fringillidae]]
*[[Cape canary]], ''Serinus canicollis'' (I) *[[Yellow-fronted canary]], ''Crithagra mozambicus'' (I)
==Sparrows== '''Order''': [[Passeriformes]]{{nbsp|3}}'''Family''': [[Passeridae]]
*[[House sparrow]], ''Passer domesticus'' (I)
==See also== *[[List of birds]] *[[Lists of birds by region]]

{{Infobox |name = Festivals of Colombia |bodystyle = |titlestyle = |abovestyle = background:#E9967A; |subheaderstyle = |title = |above = Festivals of Colombia |image = [[File:La pollera 2005.jpg|300px]][[File:Pasto 20060106 001.jpg|300px]][[File:Proseción Semana Santa en Popayán..jpg|300px]] |caption = '''Top''': [[Barranquilla's Carnival]]
'''Center''': [[Blacks and Whites' Carnival]]
'''Bottom''': [[Holy Week in Popayán]] |headerstyle = background:#EDC9AF; |header1 = General Information |label2 = Subtopics |data2 = [[Carnival in Colombia]] |label3 = Location |data3 = [[Colombia]] |label4 = Related |data4 = [[Music of Colombia]], [[cumbia]], [[vallenato]] }} The following is a list of festivals in Colombia, including [[arts festivals]], [[music festivals]], [[folk festivals]], and [[cultural festivals]], among other types. ==Festivals by type== === Traditional and cultural Colombian festivals === {{See also|Carnival in Colombia|Category:Carnival in Colombia}} '''December''' *[[Cartagena Festival Internacional de Música]] - Cartagena - Bolívar *Feria de Cali - Cali - Valle del Cauca *Feria de Manizales - Manizales - Caldas *[[Hay Festival]] - Cartagena - Bolívar *Campeonato de Voleibol Playa - Cartagena - Bolívar *Festival de La Panela - Villeta - Cundinamarca *Carnavales de Ocaña - Norte de Santander *[[Carnival of Blacks and Whites|Carnaval de Blancos y Negros]] - Pasto - Nariño *Feria Taurina de la Candelaria - Medellín - Antioquia salut les mergez *Feria Taurina - Cartagena - Bolívar *Festival de la Miel - Oiba – Santander *Fiesta de las Corralejas - Sincelejo *[[Riosucio, Caldas#Carnival of Riosucio|Carnaval de Riosucio]] - [[Riosucio, Caldas|Riosucio]] - Caldas paella *Reinado Departamental de la Panela - Villeta *Reinado del Arroz - Aguazul – Casanare *Sirenato del Mar - Tolu '''February''' *[[Barranquilla's Carnival|Carnaval de Barranquilla]] - Barranquilla - Atlántico *Feria Taurina Bogotá *Temporada Taurina - Medellín - Antioquia *Festival del Corrido Llanero - Puerto Carreño - Vichada *Festival de la Subienda - Honda – Tolima *Fiesta de la Candelaria - Cartagena - Bolívar *Carnaval del Fuego - Tumaco – Nariño '''March''' *Festival internacional de cine - Cartagena *Festival Iberoamericano de Teatro - Bogotá *Exposición Internacional de Orquídeas - Medellín *[[Holy Week in Popayán]] *Festival de Música Religiosa - Popayan - Mompox - Pamplona *Ferias y Fiestas - Acacías – Meta *Festival de la Canción Llanera - Villavicencio – Meta *Festival del Burro - San Antero – Cordoba '''April''' *Festival de Luna Verde - San Andrés *Festival Internacional de la Leyenda Vallenata - Valledupar *Feria del Cebú - San Martín – Meta *Festival del Cangrejo - San Andrés Islas *Festival de Cine Eurocine – Bogotá '''May''' *Festival de Interpretes de la Canción Mono Nuñez - Ginebra - Valle *Fiestas del San Pedro y Festival del Bunde Tolimense - Espinal - Tolima *Feria Ganadera - Socorro – Santader *Feria Internacional del Libro - Bogotá *Festival de la Cultura Wayuú - Guajira *Festival de la Cachama - Puerto Gaitan – Meta *Festival de la Arepa de Huevo - Luruaco - Atlántico *Ferias y Fiestas de Natagaima - Tolima '''June''' *Festival del Mono Nuñez - Ginebra – Valle *Festival Folclorico y Reinado Nacional del Bambuco - Neiva - Huila *Reinado Nacional del Bambuco - Neiva – Huila *Reinado Nacional del Cafe - Calarca - Quindio *Festival Folclórico del Caqueta - Florencia Caqueta *Festival Internacional de Tango- Medellín *Festival Nacional del Porro - San Pelayo – Monteria *Festival Folclórico - Ibague Tolima *Festival del Mango - San Antonio Atlántico *Feria Nacional Gallistica - Monteria *Reinado Nacional de la Ganadería - Monteria - Córdoba *Festival y Reinado del Divivi - Rioacha – Guajira *Corpus Christi - Anolaima '''July''' *Festival de la Feijoa - Tibasosa, Boyacá *Fiestas del mar - Santa Marta *Festival del sol y del acero - Sogamoso, Boyacá *Feria Agropecuaria - Charalá – Santander *Ferias y Fiestas de la Panela - Convención – Santander *Feria de la Piña - Lebrija – Santander *Festival de la Cumbia - El Banco – Magdalena *Torneo Internacional del Joropo - Villavicencio *Opera al Parque - Bogotá *[[International Poetry Festival of Medellín]] '''August''' [[File:Festival de verano rio Tùa.jpg|thumb|Festival de verano rio Tùa]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120706121000/http://www.feriadelasflores.medellin.travel/ Feria de las Flores] - Medellín *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120706121000/http://www.feriadelasflores.medellin.travel/ Desfile de Silleteros] - Medellín *Colombiamoda - Medellín *Fiestas de La Cosecha - Pereira, Risaralda *Fiestas Folclóricas - Capitanejo – Santander *Fiesta del Petróleo - Barrancabermeja *Festival de Verano - Bogotá *Festival de Tiple y la Guabina - Veléz – Santander *Festival de Cometas - Villa De Leyva *Festibuga - Buga – Valle Del Cauca *Festival de la Bahía - Bahía Solano *Festival Folclórico del Litoral Pacifico - Buenaventura *[[Boyacá International Cultural Festival]] - [[Tunja]], Boyacá '''September''' *[[Boyacá International Cultural Festival]] - [[Tunja]], Boyacá *Concurso Nacional de bandas - Paipa, Boyaca *Feria Bonita - Bucaramanga *Festival Latinoamericano de Teatro - Manizales - Caldas *Festival de la Talla en Piedra - Barichara *Festival de Música Folclórica - Socorro – Santander *Festival Cuna de {{Not a typo|Acordeones}} - Villa Nueva – Guajira *Green Moon Festival - San Andrés Islas *Festival de la Trova - Medellín *Jazz al Parque - Bogotá *Festival Internacional del Jazz del Teatro Libre - Bogotá *Fiestas de San Pacho - Quibdó - Chocó '''October''' *Reinado Nacional del Turismo - Girardot, Cundinamarca *Feria Internacional de Bogotá *Festival de Cine - Bogotá *Festival Nacional de Gaitas - Ovejas – Sucre *Festival Latinoamericano de Danzas Folclóricas - Guacarí – Valle del Cuaca *Concurso Nacional de Duos - Armenia – Quindio *Festival y Reinado Nacional del Carbón - Barrancas – Guajira) *Reinado Nacional de la Cosecha - Granada – Meta *Encuentro Mundial de Coleo - Villavicencio – Meta *Reinado Nacional de Turismo - Girardot – Cundinamarca '''November''' *Concurso Nacional de Belleza - Cartagena *Reinado Internacional de Coco - San Andres *Festival Internacional Folclórico y Turístico del Llano - San Martin - Meta *Fiesta Nacional de la Agricultura - Palmira – Valle '''December''' *Expoartesanias - Bogotá - CORFERIAS *Desfile de Danzas, Mitos y Leyendas - Medellin *Aguinaldo Boyacense - Tunja *Festival de Arte "Memoria e Imaginacion" - Cartagena *Festival de Luces - Villa De Leyva *Fiesta de Velas y Faroles - Quimbaya Quindio *Feria de Cali - Cali *Torneo Internacional de Contrapuenteo y La Voz Recia - Yopal Arauca. === Regional and folkloric festivities === {{See also|Category:Folk festivals in Colombia}} [[Image:Jipao agricola by Natalia Rivera.jpg|thumb|right|El [[Yipao]] (the jeep parade)]] *The '''[[Yipao]]''' or Jeep Parade in [[Armenia, Colombia]] * '''[[Pubenza Festivities]]''' (Spanish: Fiestas de Pubenza''), in [[Popayán]], known for its competition of ''Chirimias'' (''folkloric musical groups''). * '''[[Riosucio, Caldas#Carnival of Riosucio|Carnival of Riosucio]]''' (Spanish: ''Carnaval de Riosucio'') held in [[Riosucio, Caldas]] within the first two weeks of January every two years. In 2009 it was held from 2 to 8 January and in 2011 from 6 to 12 January. It remembers past traditions with a mixture of art, music and costumes by groups called ''cuadrillas'', drinking the traditional ''guarapo'' carried in ''calabazos''. During the carnival, the image of a cool and happy devil is exhibited. *'''Harvest Festival of Pereira''' (''Spanish: ''Fiestas de la Cosecha de Pereira''), in [[Pereira, Colombia|Pereira]]. *'''Colombian Folklore Festival''' (''Spanish: ''Festival Folklórico Colombiano'') in [[Ibagué]]. *'''Medellin's Tango Street''' (Spanish: ''Tangovía'') on [[Carlos Gardel]] Avenue in the suburb of Manrique. *'''[[Joropo]] National Festival''' (Spanish: ''Festival Nacional del Joropo'') in [[Villavicencio]] in December. *'''[[Día de las Velitas|Candles and Lanterns Festival]]''' (Spanish: ''Fiesta de Velas y Faroles'') is held in [[Quimbaya, Quindío|Quimbaya]], [[Quindío Department|Quindío]] on December 7 and 8. Each of the [[barrio]]s in the township compete to produce the most spectacular lighting arrangements. *'''Green Moon Festival''' (Spanish: ''Festival de la Luna Verde'') celebrated in the [[Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina]], this is a unique festival with characteristics that make it different from any other festival in Colombia. Here the [[Afro-Caribbean American|Afro-Caribbean]] influence is very strong, and predominance of the English-language lyrics of [[Calypso music|Calypso]] and [[Reggae]]. *'''[[National Festival of the Dividivi]]''' in [[La Guajira Department]]. *'''[[Festival of the Wayuu Culture]]''' in [[La Guajira Department]]. *'''[[Festivities of Our Lady of the Remedies]]''' in [[La Guajira Department]]. *El dia de las velas, The day of the candles held on December 7. === Film festivals === [[File:Festival01.jpg|thumb|180px|The [[Cartagena Film Festival]] is the oldest cinema event in Latin America. The central focus is on films from Ibero-America.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiapf.org/intfilmfestivals_2016_sites02.asp |publisher=fiapf.org |title=Competitive specialised film festivals |accessdate=23 May 2016}}{{cite web| url= http://www.colombia.co/cultura/ocho-festivales-de-cine-imperdibles-en-colombia.html|publisher= colombia.co |title= Ocho festivales de cine imperdibles en Colombia|language = Spanish|accessdate= 22 May 2016}}{{cite web| url= http://www.ficcifestival.com/internas.php?cod=1$$-1$$-qm4nNEHfJmY0tyUjxz05wAXG3C6fwm|publisher= ficcifestival.com |title= La Corporación Festival Internacional de Cine de Cartagena|language = Spanish|accessdate= 22 May 2016}}]] {{See also|Category:Film festivals in Colombia}} *[[Bogotá Film Festival]] *[[Cartagena Film Festival]] === Artistic and theatre festivals === [[File:Interior Teatro Colon Bogota.jpg|thumb|180px|The Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá is one of the biggest theater festivals in the world.{{cite web|url= http://es.festivaldeteatro.com.co/|title= Theater Festival|publisher= The Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá|accessdate= 11 March 2017|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170222092329/http://es.festivaldeteatro.com.co/|archivedate= 22 February 2017|df= }}]] {{See also|Category:Theatre festivals in Colombia}} * The '''[[Ibero-American Theater Festival]]''' held in [[Bogotá]] every two years, is the biggest theater festival in the world. * The '''[http://www.festivaldemanizales.org/ International Festival of Theater City of Manizales]''' * The '''[[Boyacá International Cultural Festival]]''' (Spanish: ''Festival Internacional de la Cultura de Boyacá'') held annually in [[Tunja]], is one of the biggest culture and arts festivals in Latin America. ===Music festivals=== {{See also|Category:Music festivals in Colombia}} '''Folkloric and traditional''' *[[Boyacá International Cultural Festival]] (''Festival Internacional de la Cultura de Boyacá'', [[Tunja]]. *Colombia al Parque (Bogotá) *[[Cradle of Accordions Festival]] (''Festival Cuna de Acordeones'', [[Villanueva, La Guajira]]) *[[Festival Folclórico y Reinado Nacional del Bambuco]] ([[Neiva]]) *[[Festival of the Laurels]] ([[Distracción, La Guajira]]) *[[Pubenza Festivities]] ([[Popayán]]) *Salsa al Parque (Bogotá) *[[Vallenato Legend Festival]] (''Festival de la Leyenda Vallenata'', [[Valledupar]], in April or May. The festival is a celebration of [[vallenato]] music and also a competition to find the best accordionist of the year and to select the Vallenato King (''Spanish: Rey Vallenato'') among hundreds of participants from all over the country. *[[World Day of Laziness]] ([[Itagüí]]) '''Other''' *Baum Festival (Bogotá) *[[Cali Underground]] ([[Cali]]) *[[Estéreo Picnic Festival]] (Bogotá) *Festival Internacional de Jazz (Bogotá) *Festival Latinoamérica de Concierto (Bogotá) *Hip Hop al Parque (Bogotá) *Jamming Festival (Bogotá) *Jazz al Parque (Bogotá) *Ópera al Parque (Bogotá) *[[Rock al Parque]] (Bogotá) in July, is the second largest rock festival in Latinamerica, after Rock in Rio. Around 1000 rock bands have participated in this event; both local and international bands. [[Apocalyptica]], [[Slipknot (band)|Slipknot]], [[Plastilina Mosh]] and [[Manu Chao]] have performed in Rock al Parque, among other internationally famous bands. The event is held annually in [[Simón Bolívar Park]] in Bogotá. In 2004, 400,000 people took part in the event.[http://www.rockalparque.gov.co/historia.php Rock al Parque] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707053130/http://www.rockalparque.gov.co/historia.php |date=2011-07-07 }} *Storyland Festival ([[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]]) *Manizales Grita Rock (Manizales) ==See also== {{Portal|Colombia}} *[[List of festivals]] *[[List of music festivals]] *[[List of festivals in La Guajira]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Festivals of Colombia}} {{Music festivals in Colombia}} {{Music festivals}} {{South America topic|List of festivals in}} {{South_America_in_topic|Public holidays in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Festivals In Colombia}} [[Category:Festivals in Colombia| Colombia]] [[Category:Colombia-related lists|Festivals]] [[Category:Lists of festivals by country|Colombia]] [[Category:Lists of festivals in South America|Colombia]] [[Category:Lists of festivals in Colombia| ]] [[Category:Film festivals in Colombia| ]]

revision.text:
This is a list of the '''mammal species recorded in Nauru'''. There are 4 mammal species in [[Nauru]], all of which are marine mammals of the order Cetacea.<ref>This list is derived from the [[IUCN Red List]] which lists species of mammals and includes those mammals that have recently been classified as extinct (since 1500 AD). The taxonomy and naming of the individual species is based on those used in existing Wikipedia articles as of 21 May 2007 and supplemented by the common names and taxonomy from the IUCN, Smithsonian Institution, or University of Michigan where no Wikipedia article was available. </ref>
None of the 4 species have been assessed by the [[World Conservation Union|IUCN]], as there is inadequate information to make an assessment of the risks to these species, so all are marked DD (Data Deficient).
==Subclass: [[Theria]]==
===Infraclass: [[Eutheria]]===
====Order: [[Cetacea]] (whales)==== ----
The order Cetacea includes [[whale]]s, [[dolphin]]s and [[porpoise]]s. They are the mammals most fully [[aquatic adaptation|adapted to aquatic]] life with a spindle-shaped nearly hairless body, protected by a thick layer of blubber, and forelimbs and tail modified to provide propulsion underwater.
*Suborder: [[Odontoceti]] **Superfamily: [[Platanistoidea]] ***Family: [[Ziphidae]] ****Subfamily: [[Hyperoodontinae]] *****Genus: [[Mesoplodon]] ****** [[Blainville's Beaked Whale]] ''Mesoplodon densirostris'' DD ****** [[Ginkgo-toothed Beaked Whale]] ''Mesoplodon ginkgodens'' DD ***Family: [[Delphinidae]] (marine dolphins) ****Genus: [[Lagenodelphis]] ***** [[Fraser's Dolphin]] ''Lagenodelphis hosei'' DD ****Genus: [[Feresa]] ***** [[Pygmy Killer Whale]] ''Feresa attenuata'' DD
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Use British English|date=May 2014}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2007}} {{infobox road | country = GBR | type = M | route = 180 | length_mi = 25.5 | direction = West – East | terminus_a = [[Stainforth, South Yorkshire|Stainforth]] | destinations = [[Scunthorpe]] | terminus_b = [[Elsham, Lincolnshire|Elsham]] | established = 1977 | history = Constructed 1977–79 | junction = [[File:UK-Motorway-M18.svg|1000x20px]]
[[M18 motorway (Great Britain)|M18 motorway]]
[[File:Junction 3.svg|1000x20px]] [[File:UK-Motorway-M181.svg|1000x20px]]
[[M181 motorway]] | e-road = {{BAB-E|22}} | map = M180 motorway (Great Britain) map.svg }} The '''M180''' is a {{convert|25.5|mi|}} motorway in England from junction 5 on the [[M18 motorway (Great Britain)|M18 motorway]] in the [[Metropolitan Borough of Doncaster]] to a point close to [[Humberside Airport]] some {{convert|10|mi|km|0}} from the port of [[Immingham]] and {{convert|14|mi|km|0}} from the port of [[Grimsby]] and the east coast and provides access for major routes to [[Cleethorpes]], [[Grimsby]], [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] (via the [[Humber Bridge]]), [[Immingham]], [[Lincoln, Lincolnshire|Lincoln]], [[Scunthorpe]], [[Humberside Airport]] and the Killingholme Oil Refineries; [[Humber Oil Refinery]] and [[Lindsey Oil Refinery]]. The road forms part of the unsigned [[International E-road network|Euroroute]] [[European route E22|E22]] and is the main route along the south bank of the [[Humber Estuary]]. At 25 miles long it is the longest motorway in the United Kingdom to carry a three digit number. ==History== [[File:Motorway 180 - plan.png|right|thumb|Plan of the M180 and A180]] ===Planning and construction=== The motorway bypass around Brigg was discussed for many years, but the [[Flixborough disaster|Flixborough explosion]] gave it more importance, and was built three years later in 1977 as the second section of the motorway. At this time the A15 ran through Hibaldstow and Redbourne to Brigg, and the junction with the motorway was at Castlethorpe Corner, about {{convert|1|mi|km}} east of the current A15 junction on the line of the Roman [[Ermine Street]]. The initial, and somewhat diminutive section of the motorway was the short-lived A18(M)[http://pathetic.org.uk/former/a18m/ Pathetic Motorways: A18(M)] also known as the Tudworth Link, which connected the roundabout junction with the M18 to the A18/[[A614 road|A614]]. The easterly A18(M) sliproad is still used, though the original roundabout at junction 1 has now been replaced by a bridge close to Tudworth Hall Farm. The last section to be built was the [[River Trent|Trent]] viaduct, opened in October 1979 by [[Kenneth Clarke]], despite being 43 weeks late on account of strikes and bad weather. The motorway is built to dual three-lane standard for most of its duration (aside from a short dual two-lane section past [[Scunthorpe]]), and is quite straight and flat. The M180 has its own spur – the [[M181 motorway|M181]]. While the M180 has to make do with a [[roundabout]] junction with the [[M18_motorway_(Great_Britain)|M18]], its spur has a large, freeflowing trumpet [[road junction|interchange]]. At the start of the M180 are the [[Doncaster North services]], owned by [[Moto Hospitality|Moto]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20050421114053/http://www.moto-way.com/page.cfm?Section=2&location=32 Doncaster North] === A180 extension === It was extended in the 1980s to trunk-road standard as the [[A180 road (England)|A180]] which is a two lane dual carriageway which continues on to [[Grimsby]] and [[Cleethorpes]]. In its early planning stages, it was to be named the [[A18 road (Great Britain)|A18]]. The £18 million {{convert|6|mi|km|adj=on}} section from Brigg to [[Ulceby, North Lincolnshire|Ulceby]] (A160) was opened on 29 March 1983 by [[Lynda Chalker, Baroness Chalker of Wallasey]], and the £21 million {{convert|7|mi|km|adj=on}} section from Ulceby to Grimsby opened in late 1983. == Junctions == {| border=1 cellpadding=2 style="margin-left:1em; margin-bottom: 1em; color: black; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" class="wikitable" |- align="center" bgcolor="0080d0" style="color: white;font-size:120%;" | colspan="4" | M180 motorway junctions |- align="center" bgcolor="000000" style="color: white" | Westbound exits (B carriageway) | Junction | Eastbound exits (A carriageway) | Coordinates |- align="center" | [[Doncaster]], [[Sheffield]] [[M18 motorway (Great Britain)|M18]]
''[[Doncaster North services]]'' | M18, J5
''Terminus''

''Non-motorway traffic'' | ''Road continues as [[A180 road (England)|A180]] to [[Grimsby]] and [[Cleethorpes]]'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Attached KML|display=inline,title}} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * [http://pathetic.org.uk/current/m180/ Pathetic Motorways – M180] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051202030444/http://www.iht.org/motorway/m180master.htm UK Motorway Archive.] {{UK motorways}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1-0180}} [[Category:Motorways in England]] [[Category:Borough of North Lincolnshire]] [[Category:Roads in Doncaster]] [[Category:Roads in Lincolnshire]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} The '''M.E.M. (Master of Environmental Management)''' is a degree designed for students with primary interests in careers in [[environmental policy]] and [[analysis]], [[stewardship]], [[education]], [[Consultant|consulting]], or [[management]] dealing with [[natural resource]] or [[Environmental quality|environmental]] issues. The program requires course work in both the [[Natural science|natural]] and [[social science]]s, with a particular focus on the relationship among [[science]], management, and [[policy]]. The ultimate purpose of the [[degree program]] is to prepare students to address ecological and social systems with scientific understanding and an ability to make sense of the complex underlying social and ecological context.
The value of an interdisciplinary environmental degree is best espoused by [[Aldo Leopold]], who obtained a [[Master of Forestry]] degree.
''"One of the requisites for an ecological comprehension of land is an understanding of ecology, and this is by no means co-extensive with 'education'; in fact, much higher education seems deliberately to avoid ecological concepts. An understanding of ecology does not necessarily originate in courses bearing ecological labels; it is quite as likely to be labeled geography, botany, agronomy, history, or economics. This is as it should be...".''<ref>{{cite book|last=Leopold|first=Aldo|title=A Sand County Almanac: And Sketches Here and There|year=1949|publisher=Oxford University Press, Inc.}}</ref>
The "Big Four" Master of Environmental Management programs are: * [http://www.esm.ucsb.edu/academics/MESM.html University of California, Santa Barbara - Bren School of Environmental Science and Management] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120213153527/http://www.nicholas.duke.edu/programs/professional Duke University - Nicholas School of the Environment and Earth and Ocean Sciences]
* [http://snre.umich.edu/ University of Michigan - School of Natural Resources and Environment]
* [http://environment.yale.edu/ Yale University - School of Forestry and Environmental Studies] Other programs include: *
* [https://www.pdx.edu/esm/master-of-environmental-management Portland State University - College of Liberal Arts & Sciences] * [http://www.usfca.edu/msem/ University of San Francisco - Master of Science in Environmental Management] * [http://www.umuc.edu/academic-programs/masters-degrees/environmental-management.cfm University of Maryland University College - Master of Science in Environmental Management] * [http://www.western.edu/academics/graduate-programs/master-environmental-management-mem Western State Colorado University - Master in Environmental Management]
Many of these schools also offer joint degrees, where the MEM is paired with an [[Master_of_Business_Administration|MBA]], [[Master_of_Public_Policy|MPP]], or [[Juris_Doctor|JD]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Master Of Environmental Management}} [[Category:Master's degrees|Environmental Management]] [[Category:Environmental studies]]

{{About|the Polish region|the code page in computing|Mazovia encoding}}
{{Infobox settlement | native_name = ''Mazowieckie'' | native_name_lang = pl | image_map = Mazowieckie płockie rawskie.png | mapsize = 275px | map_caption = Three historical Mazovian voivodeships in comparison with contemporary Polish voivodeships | image_shield =[[File:POL województwo mazowieckie IRP COA.svg|70px]] | subdivision_type =Country | subdivision_name ={{flag|Poland}} | timezone =[[Central European Time|CET]] | utc_offset =+1 | timezone_DST =[[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] | utc_offset_DST =+2 }}
'''Mazovia''' ({{lang-pl|Mazowieckie}}) is a historical region in mid-north-eastern [[Poland]]. It spans across the [[North European Plain]], roughly between [[Lodz]] and [[Bialystok]], with [[Warsaw]] being the unofficial capital and largest city. Throughout the centuries, Mazovia developed a separate sub-culture featuring diverse folk songs, architecture, dress and traditions different to those of other [[Poles]].
Historical Mazovia existed from the [[Middle Ages]] until the [[partitions of Poland]] and consisted of three [[voivodeship]]s with the capitals in [[Warsaw]], [[Płock]] and [[Rawa Mazowiecka|Rawa]]. The main city of the region was [[Płock]],<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=WjLUlyZdlMgC&dq=Mazowsze&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=UhVWhXC_aI&sig=mJNzDnqRNzhmQoRUO44qq7TQ0vk&hl=en&ei=snEJS-zWKYzk8AbBrtnNDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=13&ved=0CDYQ6AEwDA#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''Mazowsze: Obraz Etnograficzny''], Volume 1, by Wojciech Gerson and Oskar Kolberg, BiblioBazaar, 2009 - 372 pages</ref> however, in the [[Early Modern Times]] it lost its importance to Warsaw, which became the capital of Poland. From 1138, Mazovia was governed by a separate branch of the [[Piast dynasty]] and when the last ruler of the independent [[Duchy of Mazovia]] died, it was fully incorporated to the [[Polish Crown]] in 1526. During the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] over 20% of Mazovian population was categorized as petty [[szlachta|nobility]]. Between 1816 and 1844, the Mazovian Governorate was established, which encompassed the south of the region along with [[Łęczyca Land]] and south-eastern [[Kuyavia]]. The former inhabitants of Mazovia are the [[Masurians]], who, as [[Protestants]], took refuge in neighboring [[East Prussia]] in the later so-called region of [[Masuria]].
The borders of contemporary [[Mazovian Voivodeship]] (province), which was created in 1999, do not reflect exactly its original size as they don't include the historically Mazovian cities of [[Łomża]] and [[Łowicz]], but include the Lesser Polish [[Radom]] and [[Siedlce]].
==Geography== [[File:Mazowsze w.png|thumb|right|275px|Historical lands of Mazovia]]
Mazovia has a landscape without hills (in contrast to [[Lesser Poland]]) and without lakes (in contrast to [[Greater Poland]]). It is spread over the [[Mazovian Lowland]], on both sides of the [[Vistula]] river and its confluence with [[Narew]] and [[Bug River|Bug]]. Forests (mainly coniferous) cover one-fifth of the region, with the large [[Kampinos Forest]], [[Puszcza Biała]] and [[Puszcza Zielona]].
In the north Mazovia borders on the [[Masuria]]n subregion of former [[Prussia (region)|Prussia]], in the east on [[Podlachia]], in the south on [[Lesser Poland]] and in the west on [[Greater Poland]] (subregions of [[Łęczyca Land]], [[Kujawy]] and [[Dobrzyń Land]]). The area of Mazovia is 33,500 km<sup>2</sup>. It has population of 5 million (3 million of them inhabit the [[metropolis]] of [[Warsaw]]).
==History== When the Slavs came to this region from the surrounding area of [[Polesian Lowland|Polesie]], they mingled with the descendants of [[Vistula Veneti]]<ref>Roland Steinacher: ''Vandalen. Rezeptions- und Wissenschaftsgeschichte''. In: [[Hubert Cancik]] (Hrsg.): ''[[Der Neue Pauly]], Band 15/3''. Metzler, Stuttgart 2003, S. 942–946, {{ISBN|3-476-01489-4}}</ref><ref>Roland Steinacher: ''Wenden, Slawen, Vandalen. Eine frühmittelalterliche pseudologische Gleichsetzung und ihre Nachwirkungen bis ins 18. Jahrhundert''. In: Walter Pohl (Hrsg.): ''Die Suche nach den Ursprüngen. Von der Bedeutung des frühen Mittelalters'' (Forschungen zur Geschichte des Mittelalters; Bd. 8). Verlag der [[Österreichische Akademie der Wissenschaften|ÖAW]], Wien 2004, S. 329–353, {{ISBN|3-7001-3296-4}}.</ref> and with other people who had settled here such as the [[Wielbark culture|Wielbark]] people.<ref>J. Piontek et al. "Odontological analysis of central european populations from the Roman period and the Early Middle Ages". Humanbiologia Budapestinensis. 30. 2007. pp. 77-86. [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233752275_Odontological_Analysis_of_Central_European_Populations_from_the_Roman_Period_and_the_Early_Middle_Ages/file/9fcfd50be0d33574c9.pdf]</ref> This created a [[Lechites|Lechitic]] tribe: Mazovians.
[[File:Zamek książąt mazowieckich w Czersku 1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Czersk Castle|Castle of the Mazovian Dukes]] in [[Czersk, Masovian Voivodeship|Czersk]], 1410]]
The historical region of Mazovia (''Mazowsze'') in the beginning encompassed only the territories on the right bank of Vistula near [[Płock]] and had strong connections with [[Greater Poland]] (through [[Włocławek]] and [[Kruszwica]]). In the period of the rule of the first monarchs of the [[Piast dynasty|Piast]] State, Płock was one of their seats, and on the Cathedral Hill (Wzgórze Tumskie) they raised [[palatium]]. In the period 1037–1047 it was the capital of the independent, Mazovian state of [[Miecław|Masław]]. Between 1079 and 1138 this city was ''de facto'' the [[List of former national capitals|capital of Poland]]. Since 1075 it has been the seat of the [[diocese]] encompassing northern Mazovia; the south formed the archdeaconate of [[Czersk]] belonging to [[Poznań]], and the [[Duchy of Łowicz]] was part of the [[Gniezno]] archdiocese (this division remained as long as until the [[Partitions of Poland]]).
[[File:Anonymous Dukes of Masovia 01.jpg|thumb|right|[[Janusz III of Masovia]], Stanisław and [[Anna of Masovia]], 1520]] [[File:Nagrobek ksiazat mazowieckich sw. Jan 01.jpg|thumb|right|Tombstone of Janusz III and his brother Stanisław in [[St. John's Archcathedral, Warsaw|St. John's Archcathedral]], [[Warsaw]]]]
During the 9th century Mazovia was perhaps inhabited by the tribe of [[Mazovians]], and it was incorporated into the Polish state in the second half of 10th century under the Piast ruler [[Mieszko I]]. In 1138 the duchy of Mazovia was established, and during the 12th and 13th centuries it joined temporarily various adjacent lands and endured invasions of [[Old Prussians|Prussians]], [[Yotvingians]], and [[Ruthenians]]. To protect its northern section [[Conrad I of Mazovia]] called in the [[Teutonic Knights]] in 1226 and granted them the [[Chełmno Land]].
After the reunification of the Polish state by [[Władysław I the Elbow-high|Władysław I]] in the early 14th century, Mazovia became its fief in 1351. In the second half of 15th century western Mazovia and in 1526/1529 the main part (with its capital in Warsaw) was incorporated into the Polish state. In the 15th century the eastern part of the region ([[Łomża]]) was settled, mainly by the [[yeomanry]] (''drobna [[szlachta]]''). Mazovia was considered underdeveloped in comparison with [[Greater Poland]] and [[Lesser Poland]], with the lowest urban population.
{{Details|Duchy of Mazovia}}
In the [[Early Modern Times]] Mazovia was known for exporting grain, timber, and fur. It was also distinct because there was no [[reformation]] here. Mazovia was divided into three voivodeships, each of them divided into lands ({{lang-pl|ziemie}}, {{lang-la|terrae}}), each of them divided into counties ({{lang-pl|powiaty}}, {{lang-la|districtus}}). The Polish-[[Lithuania]]n [[Union of Lublin]] (1569) established Mazovia as the central region of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], with [[Warsaw]] rising to prominence as the seat of the state legislature (''[[sejm]]''). In 1596 King [[Sigismund III Vasa]] moved the Polish capital from [[Kraków]] to [[Warsaw]]. During the 17th and 18th centuries Swedish, Transylvanian, Saxon, and Russian invasions wreaked havoc on the region.
In 1793 western Mazovia, and two years later the rest of the region became part of Prussia (only the south-eastern portion was annexed by Austria). In 1807 it became part of the [[Duchy of Warsaw]]. In 1815 the region was incorporated into the [[Congress Kingdom of Poland]], which was dependent on Russia. In the 19th century Mazovia was the site of Polish rebellions against Russian rule. In that era pre-partition Mazovia was divided among [[Warsaw]], [[Płock]] and [[Augustów]] (the last one replaced later by [[Łomża]]).
Since 1918 Mazovia has been a part of the resurrected Poland, being roughly equivalent to the [[Warsaw Voivodeship (1975-1998)|Warsaw Voivodeship]]. Under the German occupation of Warsaw during World War II, the city’s population decreased sharply as a result of executions, the extermination of the city’s Jews, the deaths of some 200,000 inhabitants during the [[Warsaw Uprising]] of 1944, and the deportation of the city’s left-bank population following the uprising. Shortly after the uprising, [[Adolf Hitler]] ordered German troops to destroy the city. The rebuilding of the Polish capital was the main task of the postwar period.<ref name="britannica">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/659713/Mazowieckie|title=Mazowieckie | province, Poland | Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=britannica.com|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref> Those times [[Warsaw Voivodeship (1975-1998)|Warsaw Voivodeship]] was still roughly similar to historical Mazovia and used to be informally called so, but in 1975 it was divided into several little voivodeships. However, in 1999 [[Mazovian Voivodeship]] was created as one of [[Voivodeships of Poland|16 administrative regions of Poland]].
==Culture== [[File:0737 Lowitscher Volkstrachten, Sanok 2013.JPG|thumb|175px|Folk costumes from [[Łowicz]] sub-region]] ===Mazovian Dialect=== {{Details|Mazovian dialect}} The Mazovian language probably existed as a separate dialect until the 20th century.<ref name="archive">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyauniwers00moragoog/historyauniwers00moragoog_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "Historya Uniwersytetu Jagiellońskiego: Srednie wieki i odrodzenie. Z wstepem o Uniwersytecie ..."|publisher=archive.org|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | author = Felicyan Antoni Kozłowski | title = Dzieje Mazowsża za panowania książat | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hBIEAAAAYAAJ&dq=jezyk%20mazowiecki&pg=PA504#v=onepage&q&f=false | location = Warszawa | year = 1858}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | title = Kopernikijana czyli materyaly do pism i zycia Mikolaja Kopernika | url = https://archive.org/stream/kopernikijana00polkgoog/kopernikijana00polkgoog_djvu.txt | year = 1873}}</ref><ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Piśmiennictwo polskie, od czasów najdawniejszych aż do roku 1830: z rękopisów i druków zebrawszy, w obrazie literatury polskiej historycznie skreślonym|author=Maciejowski, W.A.|date=1852|volume=2|publisher=Nakładem i drukiem S. Orgelbranda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0cQaAAAAYAAJ|page=327|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="archive2">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/mitteilungen01masogoog|title=Mitteilungen : Literarische Gesellschaft Masovia : Free Download & Streaming : Internet Archive|publisher=archive.org|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref> The [[ethnonym]] ''Mazur'' has given the name for a phonetic phenomenon known as [[mazurzenie]] (although it is common in the [[Lesser Polish dialect]] as well).
===Local cuisine=== There is no specific regional cuisine of Mazovia. Formerly, dairy foods dominated the peasant cuisine. Nobles used poultry, geese, chickens, ducks. Most separate Mazovian culinary region's is [[Kurpie]] and [[Łowicz]], where traditional dishes survive to the present day. In Kurpie traditional dishes are prepared with ingredients collected in the forest: berries, honey and mushrooms. There are several [[Polish cuisine|traditional Polish dishes]], e.g. [[flaki]], [[kluski]], which are prepared in different way than in other parts of Poland.<ref>[http://www.foody.pl/strony/1/i/1009.php Kuchnia Mazowsza i Kurpiów] – Kuchnia Polska</ref><ref>[http://www.kuron.com.pl/widelcem_po_mapie/art4.html Potrawy mazowieckie] – Kuron.com.pl</ref>
==Economy== [[Mazovian Voivodeship]] is ranked decidedly first in Poland according to the [[Gross Domestic Product]].<ref name="forsal">{{cite web|url=http://forsal.pl/artykuly/366983,mazowsze_jest_i_bedzie_najbogatsze_w_polsce.html |title=Mazowsze jest i będzie najbogatsze w Polsce - Analizy rynku - Forsal.pl - Giełda, Waluty, Finanse – forex, notowania NBP, surowce |publisher=forsal.pl|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref> This is thanks to Warsaw, which is a financial centre of [[East-Central Europe]].<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/nov2010/gb2010113_805361.htm Warsaw: Central Europe's Bourse to Beat] - BusinessWeek</ref><ref>[http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2010/12/13/2003490805 Warsaw makes bid to become Central Europe’s financial hub] – Taipei Times</ref> The majority of state enterprises are headquartered in this [[metropolis]]. It is a hub for both rail and vehicular traffic, with access throughout Poland and across Europe. [[Warsaw Chopin Airport]] is the nation’s busiest. There are many branches of industry and sercives well developed in this city. The other eonomical center is [[Płock]], where large petrochemical plants [[PKN Orlen]] operate. The rest of Mazovia belongs to the poorest parts of Poland. In the agriculture the most typical Mazovian crops are potatoes and [[rye]], but the most popular (as in whole Poland) is wheat. Others are [[barley]], [[sugar beets]], [[fruits]] (with their biggest Polish ''basin'' in the south of the region), and vegetables. Pigs are commonly bred, often also cows and chickens.
==Tourism== [[File:Manor house in Żelazowa Wola.JPG|thumb|right|Birthplace of [[Fryderyk Chopin]] in [[Żelazowa Wola]]]] [[Kampinos National Park]] is one of Poland’s largest national parks and is popular with tourists making day trips from Warsaw to hike among the park’s primeval forests, sand dunes, and marshland. The main cultural centre of the region, and, alongside [[Kraków]], in all of Poland, is Warsaw, which is home to dozens of theatres, the National Philharmonic, the National Opera House, the National Library, the National Museum, [[Centrum Nauki Kopernik]], [[Muzeum Powstania Warszawskiego]], [[Temple of Divine Providence]], and the [[Sanctuary of Blessed Jerzy Popiełuszko]]. Warsaw has many magnificent historic buildings and monuments, including those in the Old Town and the New Town, both of which were almost completely demolished during World War II but were meticulously restored and were designated UNESCO World Heritage sites in 1980. Several important edifices has been built at the adjacent street [[Krakowskie Przedmieście]]. There are also royal palaces and gardens of [[Łazienki]] and [[Wilanów]]. The most interesting building from post-war period is [[Pałac Kultury i Nauki]].
Historical monuments elsewhere include the manor house in [[Żelazowa Wola]] where composer [[Frédéric Chopin]] was born and his museum is located nowadays. Płock, once the seat of the Mazovian princes, and [[Łowicz]], the residence of the archbishops of [[Gniezno]], are noted for their [[cathedral]]s. There are also [[palace]]s and parks in [[Nieborów]] and [[Arkadia]], the [[Modlin Fortress]], [[castle]]s in [[Czersk]], [[Pułtusk]], [[Ciechanów]], [[Opinogóra Górna|Opinogóra]], [[Rawa Mazowiecka]], [[Sochaczew]] and [[Liw, Poland|Liw]], as well as churches in [[Niepokalanów]], [[Góra Kalwaria]], [[Warka]], [[Skierniewice]], [[Czerwińsk]], [[Wyszogród]], [[Zakroczym]], [[Szreńsk]], [[Przasnysz]], [[Ostrołęka]], [[Łomża]], [[Szczuczyn]], [[Wizna]], [[Brok, Masovian Voivodeship|Brok]], [[Zuzela]], [[Rostkowo, Płock County|Rostkowo]], and [[Boguszyce, Rawa County|Boguszyce]]. Interesting [[folklore]] is found in the subregion of [[Kurpie]]; another [[skansen]] has been established in [[Sierpc]].<ref name="britannica2">{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/659713/Mazowieckie |title=Mazowieckie | province, Poland | Encyclopædia Britannica |publisher=britannica.com|accessdate=10 April 2015}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{about|a type of historic document|the modern ''Periplus Series''|Tuttle Publishing}} [[File:Arrian, Periplus.jpg|thumb|Beginning of the Arrian Periplous Euxeinou Pontou of Johann Froben and Nicolaus Episcopius, Basel 1533]] A '''periplus''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɛr|ɪ|p|l|ʌ|s}}) is a manuscript document that lists the ports and coastal landmarks, in order and with approximate intervening distances, that the captain of a vessel could expect to find along a shore.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Source Book in Geography|first=George|last=Kish|page=21|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge|year=1978|isbn=0-674-82270-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_6qF4vjZvhYC }}</ref> In that sense the periplus was a type of log. It served the same purpose as the later Roman [[itinerarium]] of road stops; however, the Greek navigators added various notes, which if they were professional geographers (as many were) became part of their own additions to Greek geography.
The form of the ''periplus'' is at least as old as the earliest Greek historian, the Ionian [[Hecataeus of Miletus]]. The works of [[Herodotus]] and [[Thucydides]] contain passages that appear to have been based on ''peripli''.<ref>{{cite book|page=40|title=Josephus Geographicus: The Classical Context of Geography in Josephus|first=Yuval|last=Shahar|publisher=Mohr Siebeck|year=2004|isbn=3-16-148256-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIJLJSYFogUC&pg=PA40 }}</ref>
==Etymology== ''Periplus'' is the Latinization of the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] word περίπλους (''periplous'', contracted from περίπλοος ''periploos''), is "a sailing-around." Both segments, ''peri-'' and ''-plous'', were independently [[Productivity (linguistics)|productive]]: the ancient Greek speaker understood the word in its literal sense; however, it developed a few specialized meanings, one of which became a standard term in the ancient navigation of [[Phoenicians]], [[Greeks]], and [[Ancient Rome|Romans]].
==Known ''peripli''== Several examples of ''peripli'' that are known to scholars:
=== Carthaginian ===
*The Periplus of [[Himilco the Navigator]], parts which are preserved in [[Pliny the Elder]] and [[Avienus]].<ref>[[Nicholas Purcell (classicist)|Nicholas Purcell]] "Himilco" in ''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]]'' 3rd. ed. [[Oxford]]; [[Oxford University Press]] 1999 p.707</ref> *The [[Hanno the Navigator#Periplus account|Periplus]] of [[Hanno the Navigator]], [[Carthage|Carthaginian]] colonist and explorer who explored the coast of [[Africa]] from present-day [[Morocco]] southward at least as far as [[Senegal]] in the sixth or fifth century BCE.<ref>{{cite book |translator-first=H. |translator-last=Schoff |title=The Periplus of Hanno a voyage of discovery down the west African coast |year=1912 |url=https://openlibrary.org/books/OL6541953M/The_Periplus_of_Hanno }}</ref>
=== Greek ===
*The ''Periplus'' of the Greek [[Scylax of Caryanda]], in Caria, who allegedly sailed down the [[Indus River]] and then to [[Suez]] on the initiative of [[Darius I]]. This voyage is mentioned by [[Herodotus]], and his pleriplus is quoted by Hecataeus of Miletus, [[Aristotle]], [[Strabo]] and Avienus.<ref>"Scylax" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.1374</ref> *The ''[[Massaliote Periplus]]'', a description of trade routes along the coasts of [[Atlantic Europe]], by anonymous Greek navigators of Massalia (now Marseille, France), possibly dates to the sixth century BCE, also preserved in Avienus<ref>"Periploi" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.1141</ref> *[[Pytheas of Massilia]], (fourth century BCE) ''On the Ocean'' (Περί του Ωκεανού), has not survived; only excerpts remain, quoted or paraphrased by later authors, including Strabo, [[Diodorus Siculus]], Pliny the Elder and in Avienus' ''Ora maritima''.<ref>"Pytheas" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.1285</ref> *The ''[[Periplus of Pseudo-Scylax]]'', generally is thought to date to the fourth or third century BCE.<ref>"Scylax" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.1374</ref> *The Pleriplus of [[Nearchus]] surveyed the area between the Indus and the Persian Gulf under orders from [[Alexander the Great]]. He was a source for Strabo and [[Arrian]], among others.<ref>"Periploi" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.1141</ref> *''On the Red Sea'' by [[Agatharchides]]. Fragments preserved in Diodorus Siculus and [[Photius]].<ref>"Agatharchides" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.36</ref> * The Periplus of [[Scymnus]] of [[Chios]] is dated to around 110 BCE.<ref>"Scymnus" in ''OCD''<sup>3</sup> p.137436</ref> *The ''[[Periplus of the Erythraean Sea]]'' or Red Sea was written by a Greek of the Hellenistic/Romanized [[Alexandria]]n in the first century CE. It provides a shoreline itinerary of the [[Red Sea|Red (Erythraean) Sea]], starting at the port of [[Berenice (port)|Berenice]]. Beyond the Red Sea, the manuscript describes the coast of India as far as the [[Ganges River]] and the east coast of Africa (called [[Azania]]). The unknown author of the ''Periplus of the Erythraean Sea'' claims that Hippalus, a mariner, was knowledgeable about the "monsoon winds" that shorten the round-trip from India to the Red Sea.{{sfn|Liu|2010|p=34}} Also according to the manuscript, the Horn of Africa was called, "the Cape of Spices,"{{sfn|Liu|2010|p=36}} and modern day Yemen was known as the "Frankincense Country."{{sfn|Liu|2010|p=37}} *The ''[[Periplus Ponti Euxini]]'', a description of trade routes along the coasts of the [[Black Sea]], written by [[Arrian]] (in Greek Αρριανός) in the early second century CE.
==''Rahnāmag''== [[Persia]]n sailors had long had their own sailing guide books, called ''Rahnāmag'' in [[Middle Persian]] (''Rahnāmeh'' رهنامه in [[Modern Persian]]).<ref>{{cite book |last=Dehkhoda |first=Ali Akbar |first2=Mohammad |last2=Moʻin |year=1958 |title=Loghat-namehʻi Dehkhoda |location=Tehran |publisher=Tehran University Press: Rahnāma }}</ref>
They listed the ports and coastal landmarks and distances along the shores.
The lost but much-cited sailing directions go back at least to the 12th century. Some described the [[Indian Ocean]] as "a hard sea to get out of" and warned of the "circumambient sea," with all return impossible.<ref>{{cite book |title=Civilizations: Culture, Ambition, and the Transformation of Nature |first=Felipe |last=Fernandez-Armesto |location=New York |publisher=Free Press |year=2001 |isbn=0-7432-0248-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TJcSAQAAIAAJ }}</ref>
==Tactic of naval combat== A ''periplus'' was also an ancient naval manoeuvre in which attacking ''[[triremes]]'' would outflank or encircle the defenders to attack them in the rear.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
==See also== * [[List of Graeco-Roman geographers]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |ref=harv |first=Xinru |last=Liu |author-link=Xinru Liu |title=The Silk Road in World History |location=New York |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2010}}
==External links== * {{wiktionary-inline|periplus}}
